pdhp1:0.2.verse: Hail and Homage to all Buddhas, Dharmas and the Noble Saṅghas.

pdhp1:1.verse: Mind precedes thoughts, mind is their chief, they are impelled by mind,

pdhp1:2.verse: if with a base mind one speaks or acts,

pdhp1:3.verse: through that, suffering follows him like a wheel follows the ox’s foot.

pdhp2:1.verse: Mind precedes thoughts, mind is their chief, they are impelled by mind,

pdhp2:2.verse: if with pure mind one speaks or acts,

pdhp2:3.verse: through that, happiness follows him like a shadow which does not depart.

pdhp3:1.verse: Here he laments, after death he laments, the wicked one laments in both places,

pdhp3:2.verse: he laments, he suffers vexation, seeing the defilement of his own deeds.

pdhp4:1.verse: Here he is happy, after death he is happy, the meritorious one is happy in both places,

pdhp4:2.verse: he is happy… seeing the purity of his own deeds.

pdhp5:1.verse: “He abused me, he struck at me, he overcame me, he robbed me,”

pdhp5:2.verse: those who bear these ill-will their hatred is never appeased.

pdhp6:1.verse: “He abused me, he struck at me, he overcame me, he robbed me,”

pdhp6:2.verse: those who do not bear these ill-will their hatred is appeased.

pdhp7:1.verse: Living contemplating what is pleasant, uncontrolled in sense faculties,

pdhp7:2.verse: not knowing the limit in food, indolent, low in energy—

pdhp7:3.verse: Māra surely overthrows that one, like wind overthrows a weak tree.

pdhp8:1.verse: Living contemplating the unpleasant, well-controlled in sense faculties,

pdhp8:2.verse: and knowing the limit in food, faithful, with energy aroused—

pdhp8:3.verse: Māra does not overthrow that one, just as wind does not overthrow a mountain made of rock.

pdhp9:1.verse: If you should find a prudent, wise companion, one who lives well, a wise one,

pdhp9:2.verse: overcoming all your troubles you should live with that one, glad and mindful.

pdhp10:1.verse: If you do not find a prudent, wise companion, one who lives well, a wise one,

pdhp10:2.verse: like a king who abandons his conquered kingdom, one should live alone like a solitary elephant in the forest.

pdhp11:1.verse: It is better to live alone, there can be no companionship with a fool,

pdhp11:2.verse: one should live alone and not do anything bad, unconcerned like a solitary elephant in the forest.

pdhp12:1.verse: He who, through desire, hatred, fear or delusion, transgresses Dhamma,

pdhp12:2.verse: his fame diminishes, like the moon in the dark fortnight.

pdhp13:1.verse: He who, through desire, hatred, fear or delusion, does not transgress Dhamma,

pdhp13:2.verse: his fame increases, like the moon in the bright fortnight.

pdhp14:1.verse: Heedfulness is the deathless state, heedlessness the state of the dead,

pdhp14:2.verse: the heedful do not die, but those who are heedless are as if dead.

pdhp15:1.verse: The wise, understanding this difference in regard to heedfulness,

pdhp15:2.verse: rejoice in heedfulness, delight in the domain of the Noble Ones.

pdhp16:1.verse: Those who meditate all the time, constant and firm in their effort,

pdhp16:2.verse: those wise ones reach Nibbāna, the unsurpassed release from all bonds.

pdhp17:1.verse: The foolish and stupid people cultivate heedlessness,

pdhp17:2.verse: but the sagacious one guards heedfulness just as his greatest wealth.

pdhp18:1.verse: Heedful amongst the heedless ones, wakeful amongst the ones who sleep,

pdhp18:2.verse: like a swift horse who abandons a weak horse, the true sage moves on.

pdhp19:1.verse: When the wise one eliminates heedlessness with his heedfulness,

pdhp19:2.verse: and mounts the palace of wisdom, griefless, he looks on grieving people;

pdhp19:3.verse: the wise one, like one standing on a mountain, looks down on the fools who are standing on the plains.

pdhp20:1.verse: Whoever before was heedless, but later is not heedless,

pdhp20:2.verse: that one shines brightly in this world like the moon released from a cloud.

pdhp21:1.verse: Whoever before was heedless, but later is not heedless,

pdhp21:2.verse: he, being mindful, can overcome clinging to the world.

pdhp22:1.verse: A monastic who values heedfulness, seeing danger in heedlessness,

pdhp22:2.verse: is unable to fall away: he is well-nigh to Nibbāna.

pdhp23:1.verse: A monastic who values heedfulness, seeing danger in heedlessness,

pdhp23:2.verse: advances like burning fire against the fetter, small or large.

pdhp24:1.verse: You should delight in heedfulness, you should always protect your mind,

pdhp24:2.verse: you should raise yourself from this pit like the tusker sunk in the mud.

pdhp25:1.verse: Rejoicing in heedfulness, prudent, restrained in virtue,

pdhp25:2.verse: in good time they attain that where, once attained, there is no grieving.

pdhp26:1.verse: Do not rejoice in heedlessness, unacquainted with delight in sensual pleasure,

pdhp26:2.verse: living in this way, ardent, with mind at peace, not proud,

pdhp26:3.verse: devoted to mental calm, he will make an end to suffering.

pdhp27:1.verse: One should strive, not be heedless, one should live by Dhamma, with good conduct,

pdhp27:2.verse: living by Dhamma one lives at ease in this world and the next.

pdhp28:1.verse: For he who is active, mindful, pure in deeds, considerate,

pdhp28:2.verse: self-controlled, living by Dhamma, heedful, his fame increases.

pdhp29:1.verse: Through activity, heedfulness, through self-control and through restraint,

pdhp29:2.verse: the sage should make an island that no flood waters can overwhelm.

pdhp30:1.verse: The one who has not energy at a time for energy, youthful, strong, lazy in his home,

pdhp30:2.verse: whose mind lacks right intention and is indolent—the lazy one does not go along wisdom’s path.

pdhp31:1.verse: One should not follow lowly things, one should not abide heedlessly,

pdhp31:2.verse: one should not follow a wrong view, one should not foster worldliness.

pdhp32:1.verse: One is not a Dhamma-bearer merely through speaking much,

pdhp32:2.verse: but the one who, having heard a little, would see Dhamma for himself,

pdhp32:3.verse: is one who bears Dhamma, the one who is not heedless regarding Dhamma.

pdhp33:1.verse: Consider the Dhamma heedfully, do not let your mind swirl around in strands of desire,

pdhp33:2.verse: do not, heedless, swallow a hot iron ball, and, while burning, cry: ‘This is suffering.’

pdhp34:1.verse: Strive and cut off the thread, remove continuity, brahmin,

pdhp34:2.verse: knowing the destruction of the conditioned, you are … brahmin

pdhp35:1.verse: That one from whom one learned Dhamma, whether old or young,

pdhp35:2.verse: with respect bow down to him, like a brahmin bows at fire-sacrifice.

pdhp36:1.verse: That one from whom one learned Dhamma taught by the Perfect Sambuddha,

pdhp36:2.verse: you should honor him, like a brahmin honors the fire-sacrifice.

pdhp37:1.verse: Not because of matted hair, family or birth is one a true brahmin,

pdhp37:2.verse: he who wards off wickedness, small or great, in every way,

pdhp37:3.verse: through warding off wickedness, he is called a brahmin.

pdhp38:1.verse: Like water on the lotus leaf, like a mustard seed on a needle,

pdhp38:2.verse: he who is unsmeared by desires, that one I say is a brahmin.

pdhp39:1.verse: The sun is radiant when it rises, the moon shines by night,

pdhp39:2.verse: the accoutred noble is radiant, the meditating brahmin is radiant,

pdhp39:3.verse: yet during every day and night the Buddha is radiant through his power.

pdhp40:1.verse: For whom the near shore, the far shore or both do not exist,

pdhp40:2.verse: free of fever, detached, that one I say is a brahmin.

pdhp41:1.verse: When a brahmin has, through two things, crossed over,

pdhp41:2.verse: then, for one who knows, all the fetters are laid to rest.

pdhp42:1.verse: He who destroyed the fetter, destroyed conceit and continued existence,

pdhp42:2.verse: living in the Community, standing by Dhamma, the knowing one does not approach society.

pdhp43:1.verse: Whoever should speak a word of truth that is informed and is not coarse,

pdhp43:2.verse: through which no one would be cursed, that one I say is a brahmin.

pdhp44:1.verse: Whoever doesn’t mix with either householders or the houseless,

pdhp44:2.verse: wandering homeless, with few desires, that one I say is a brahmin.

pdhp45:1.verse: For whom there is no wrong-doing bodily, verbally or mentally,

pdhp45:2.verse: being restrained in these three things, that one I say is a brahmin.

pdhp46:1.verse: A brahmin should not hit a brahmin, nor should he abandon him,

pdhp46:2.verse: woe to the one who strikes a brahmin, and to the one who does not abandon him.

pdhp47:1.verse: Destroying mother first, and then two noble kings,

pdhp47:2.verse: destroying a kingdom and its followers, the brahmin lives untroubled.

pdhp48:1.verse: The deeply wise sagacious one, skilled in what is path and not path,

pdhp48:2.verse: who has reached the ultimate good, that one I say is a brahmin.

pdhp49:1.verse: The meditator sitting down, the one who is dustless, who has done his duty, without pollutants,

pdhp49:2.verse: who has reached the ultimate good, that one I say is a brahmin.

pdhp50:1.verse: Restraint is good everywhere, restraint is everywhere good,

pdhp50:2.verse: a monastic who is restrained everywhere is liberated from all suffering.

pdhp51:1.verse: Restraint of body is good, restraint of speech is good,

pdhp51:2.verse: restraint of mind is also good, restraint is everywhere good,

pdhp51:3.verse: a monastic who is restrained everywhere is liberated from all suffering.

pdhp52:1.verse: One who controls his hands, controls his feet, controls his speech, controls the mind faculty,

pdhp52:2.verse: with inner delight and composure, solitary, content: that one is called a monastic.

pdhp53:1.verse: Calm in body and calm in mind, having calmness and composure,

pdhp53:2.verse: having thrown off worldly gain the monastic is called one at peace.

pdhp54:1.verse: That monastic who restrains the mouth, who speaks well, and who is modest,

pdhp54:2.verse: who teaches the meaning of the Dhamma, his speech is sweet.

pdhp55:1.verse: One should not despise one’s own gains, one should not live envious of others,

pdhp55:2.verse: the monastic who is envious of others does not attain concentration.

pdhp56:1.verse: Even if a monastic gains little he should not despise his gains,

pdhp56:2.verse: even the very gods praise the one of pure life who is diligent.

pdhp57:1.verse: Please bail out this boat, monastic, when bailed out it will go lightly,

pdhp57:2.verse: cutting off passion and hatred, from here one will go to Nibbāna.

pdhp58:1.verse: With uplifted mind, happy, having overcome what is dear and not dear,

pdhp58:2.verse: then with lots of happiness, the monastic should wander mindfully.

pdhp59:1.verse: That monastic who dwells in loving-kindness, with faith in Buddha’s dispensation,

pdhp59:2.verse: has penetrated the state of peace, the joy in stilling of all conditions,

pdhp59:3.verse: here and now there is Nibbāna, the unsurpassed release from all bonds.

pdhp60:1.verse: For the one who has entered an empty place, a monastic with a peaceful mind,

pdhp60:2.verse: there is superhuman delight from insight into true Dhamma.

pdhp61:1.verse: Just as one with right mindfulness regarding the rise and fall of the components of mind and body

pdhp61:2.verse: gains happiness in mind, this is the deathless state for the one who knows.

pdhp62:1.verse: There is no concentration for one without wisdom, there is no wisdom for one without concentration,

pdhp62:2.verse: that one in whom there is concentration and wisdom is indeed close to Nibbāna.

pdhp63:1.verse: This is the very beginning for the wise monastic here:

pdhp63:2.verse: contentment, guarding the senses, and restraint in the regulations.

pdhp64:1.verse: One should resort to spiritual friends, ones of pure life, ones who are diligent,

pdhp64:2.verse: one should be one of friendly disposition, one who will be skilful in conduct,

pdhp64:3.verse: rejoicing frequently because of that, the monastic should wander mindfully.

pdhp65:1.verse: Friends are good whenever need arises, at the break-up of life merit is good,

pdhp65:2.verse: being content with everything is good, the abandoning of all wickedness is good.

pdhp66:1.verse: Respecting one’s mother is good in the world, also respecting one’s father is good,

pdhp66:2.verse: respecting ascetics is good in the world, also respecting true brahmins is good.

pdhp67:1.verse: Virtuous conduct till old age is good, the establishing of faith is good,

pdhp67:2.verse: speech that is beneficial is good, the destruction of conceit is good.

pdhp68:1.verse: The arising of the Buddhas is good, the teaching of the Dhamma is good,

pdhp68:2.verse: the harmony of the Saṅgha is good, devotion to harmony is good.

pdhp69:1.verse: Meeting with the noble is pleasant, living with good people is pleasant,

pdhp69:2.verse: through not meeting foolish people one will constantly be happy.

pdhp70:1.verse: For he who consorts with fools grieves for a long time,

pdhp70:2.verse: dwelling with fools is always suffering as it is with enemies,

pdhp70:3.verse: the wise ones dwell happily as with an assembly of kin.

pdhp71:1.verse: Therefore the firm and the learned, the virtuous, dutiful and noble—

pdhp71:2.verse: follow such a true and intelligent person as the moon follows the course of the stars.

pdhp72:1.verse: From love there arises grief, with love grief, with love fear,

pdhp72:2.verse: for one who is free from love there is no grief, how is there fear?

pdhp73:1.verse: Do not associate at any time with those who are loved or with those unloved,

pdhp73:2.verse: there is suffering not meeting the loved one, and suffering from meeting the unloved one.

pdhp74:1.verse: Therefore do not hold anything as loved, for speaking of the loved is loathsome.

pdhp74:2.verse: There are no knots for those who hold nothing as loved or as unloved.

pdhp75:1.verse: Hunger is the supreme sickness, conditions are the supreme suffering,

pdhp75:2.verse: knowing this as it really is, know Nibbāna is the supreme good.

pdhp76:1.verse: Health is the supreme gain, content the supreme wealth,

pdhp76:2.verse: confidence the supreme kin, Nibbāna the supreme good.

pdhp77:1.verse: If, by renouncing a small good, he might see a good that is large,

pdhp77:2.verse: the wise one should renounce that small good, seeing the good that is extensive.

pdhp78:1.verse: For a human who is always mindful, knowing the measure in food received,

pdhp78:2.verse: his painful feelings become slight, he ages slowly, guarding his lifespan.

pdhp79:1.verse: A person of good breed is rare, that one is not born everywhere,

pdhp79:2.verse: wherever that hero is born, that family gains happiness.

pdhp80:1.verse: There are surely true people everywhere, the good do not talk of desiring sense-pleasures;

pdhp80:2.verse: when touched by pleasure or by suffering, true people are not elated or depressed.

pdhp81:1.verse: The victor generates hatred, the defeated one finds suffering,

pdhp81:2.verse: the one at peace lives happily, having abandoned victory and defeat.

pdhp82:1.verse: Pleasant are rivers with good fords, pleasant is the person conquered by Dhamma,

pdhp82:2.verse: the acquisition of faith is good, doing nothing wicked is good.

pdhp83:1.verse: It is pleasant to meet the virtuous, it is pleasant to meet the learned,

pdhp83:2.verse: it is pleasant to meet the Worthy Ones, who are free from attachments.

pdhp84:1.verse: Whatever griefs or lamentations there are, and the many kinds of suffering in the world,

pdhp84:2.verse: these all arise because of love, without loves, these do not originate.

pdhp85:1.verse: Therefore they are happy and free from grief, who are without love for anything in the world,

pdhp85:2.verse: therefore those wanting what is griefless, dust-free, should not have love for anything in the world.

pdhp86:1.verse: For the one who has reached his goal, who grieves not, being released on all sides,

pdhp86:2.verse: who has abandoned all the knots, no consuming fever is found.

pdhp87:1.verse: For those who have no stores, those who comprehend food aright,

pdhp87:2.verse: like the birds in the sky, their footprint is hard to find.

pdhp88:1.verse: His mind is calm, his speech and his actions are also calm,

pdhp88:2.verse: liberated by right knowledge, such a one is truly peaceful.

pdhp89:1.verse: For the one whose senses are balanced, like horses well-trained by their charioteer,

pdhp89:2.verse: who has abandoned conceit, who is without pollutants—even the gods envy such a one.

pdhp90:1.verse: They lead one trained into a crowd, a king mounts one who has been trained,

pdhp90:2.verse: amongst humans one trained is best, the one who can endure reproof.

pdhp91:1.verse: Noble are the well-trained horses, the well-bred horses from Sindh,

pdhp91:2.verse: and the great tusker elephants, and even more noble than that is the one who has trained himself.

pdhp92:1.verse: Not by these vehicles can one reach that place,

pdhp92:2.verse: as one through training himself well, being trained by the training, goes.

pdhp93:1.verse: Just as solid rock is not shaken by the wind,

pdhp93:2.verse: so the wise are not shaken by blame or praise.

pdhp94:1.verse: The one who, while still impure, would wear the renunciant’s robe,

pdhp94:2.verse: unendowed with restraint and truth, is not worthy of the renunciant’s robe.

pdhp95:1.verse: The one who, steady in virtue, throws out any impurity,

pdhp95:2.verse: endowed with restraint and truth, is indeed worthy of the renunciant’s robe.

pdhp96:1.verse: Hasten to do wholesome deeds, ward off the mind from wickedness,

pdhp96:2.verse: for the mind of the one slow in merit delights in wickedness.

pdhp97:1.verse: Should a person do that which is wicked, he should not do it again and again,

pdhp97:2.verse: let him not place his intention in it, for there is an accumulation of suffering for the wicked one.

pdhp98:1.verse: If a person should make merit, he should do it again and again,

pdhp98:2.verse: let him place his intention there, there is an increase of joy for the one who has made merit.

pdhp99:1.verse: For the pure one there is always fasting, for the pure one there is always the fast day,

pdhp99:2.verse: for the pure one, the one of clean deeds, his vow always succeeds.

pdhp100:1.verse: Better undone is a wrong-doing, a wrong-doing one later regrets,

pdhp100:2.verse: he grieves, thinking: “I have done a bad deed,” gone to a bad fate, he grieves much more.

pdhp101:1.verse: Better done is what is well-done, which, when done, one does not regret

pdhp101:2.verse: he is happy, thinking: “I have done a good deed,” gone to a good fate, he is happy much more.

pdhp102:1.verse: Even the wicked one experiences good fortune while the wickedness does not ripen,

pdhp102:2.verse: but when the wickedness ripens then the wicked one experiences wicked things.

pdhp103:1.verse: Even the fortunate one experiences wickedness as long as the good fortune does not ripen,

pdhp103:2.verse: but when the fortune ripens then the fortunate one experiences good fortune.

pdhp104:1.verse: Even the wicked one does good while the wickedness does not ripen,

pdhp104:2.verse: but when the time has gone by the wicked one experiences wicked things.

pdhp105:1.verse: Even the fortunate one does wickedness as long as the good fortune does not ripen,

pdhp105:2.verse: but when the time has gone by the fortunate one experiences good fortune.

pdhp106:1.verse: If there is no wound for him in his hand he can carry poison with his hand,

pdhp106:2.verse: poison does not enter without a wound, there is no wickedness for the one who does not do wrong.

pdhp107:1.verse: A wicked deed that has been done, like milk, does not turn all at once,

pdhp107:2.verse: smouldering, it follows the fool, like a fire covered with ashes.

pdhp108:1.verse: A wicked deed that has been done, like a knife, does not cut all at once,

pdhp108:2.verse: but when death comes he knows the destiny of those who do wickedness.

pdhp109:1.verse: You should prepare beforehand what is to be done, do not tremble at what is to be done at the time for it,

pdhp109:2.verse: for such a one who has prepared what is to be done, does not tremble at what is to be done at the time for it.

pdhp110:1.verse: One should prepare to do that which one knows is for one’s welfare,

pdhp110:2.verse: the sage, the wise one should make effort, not with the thinking of the charioteer.

pdhp111:1.verse: As the charioteer who abandoned the smooth path of the highway,

pdhp111:2.verse: and approached the rough path, then he broods, as upon a broken axle,

pdhp112:1.verse: so the one departing from Dhamma and following what is not Dhamma,

pdhp112:2.verse: when that fool comes to Death’s jaws he broods, as upon a broken axle.

pdhp113:1.verse: Many wearing the monastic robe around their necks are wicked, unrestrained.

pdhp113:2.verse: Wicked ones! Through your wicked deeds, you re-arise in the underworld.

pdhp114:1.verse: One who speaks what is untrue goes to the underworld, he who says: ‘I do not do’ what he has done,

pdhp114:2.verse: both of these are just the same when they have gone to the hereafter, they are humans who did base deeds.

pdhp115:1.verse: He who offends against the inoffensive one, a purified and passionless person:

pdhp115:2.verse: that wicked deed then returns to the fool, like fine dust that is thrown against the wind.

pdhp116:1.verse: Like a merchant on a fearful path, with few friends and great wealth,

pdhp116:2.verse: as one loving life would avoid poison, so should one avoid wicked deeds.

pdhp117:1.verse: He who desires happiness for himself by causing suffering for another,

pdhp117:2.verse: being associated thus with hatred, is not fully released from suffering.

pdhp118:1.verse: The smell of a corpse is cut off eventually, also of one bloated when nights have passed,

pdhp118:2.verse: but of the man who lives not by Dhamma day by day his smell is never cut off.

pdhp119:1.verse: Just as householders having great treasures, when the city is on fire and burning,

pdhp119:2.verse: because of their pearls, jewels, crystal and silver, make effort, thinking: “We will save something”,

pdhp120:1.verse: so the ascetics of great wisdom, noble ones training along the noble path,

pdhp120:2.verse: oppressed with the fear of birth, old age, death, afflicted by suffering, make effort, thinking: “We will attain peace”.

pdhp121:1.verse: The fragrance of flowers goes not against the wind, nor does sandalwood or pinwheel or saffron,

pdhp121:2.verse: but the fragrance of the good goes against the wind, the true person’s fragrance permeates all directions.

pdhp122:1.verse: Sandalwood, pinwheel, then water lily and striped jasmine,

pdhp122:2.verse: amongst these kinds of fragrance virtue’s fragrance is unsurpassed.

pdhp123:1.verse: Pinwheel and sandalwood fragrance are insignificant,

pdhp123:2.verse: but the fragrance of those who have virtue flutters supreme amongst the gods.

pdhp124:1.verse: Māra cannot find the path of those endowed with virtue, who live heedfully,

pdhp124:2.verse: and who are freed through right and deep knowledge.

pdhp125:1.verse: Just like a beautiful flower, which has colour, but lacks fragrance,

pdhp125:2.verse: so are well-spoken words fruitless for the one who acts not on them.

pdhp126:1.verse: Just like a beautiful flower, which has colour, and has fragrance,

pdhp126:2.verse: so are well-spoken words fruitful for the one who does act on them.

pdhp127:1.verse: Just as a bee, without hurting the flower, its colour or scent,

pdhp127:2.verse: gathers its nectar and escapes, so should the seer roam in the village.

pdhp128:1.verse: Death takes up and carries away the one whose mind is attached to collecting flowers,

pdhp128:2.verse: like a great flood carries off a sleeping village.

pdhp129:1.verse: The End-Maker takes control of the one whose mind is attached to collecting flowers,

pdhp129:2.verse: though he is unfulfilled with sense pleasures.

pdhp130:1.verse: Just as from a heap of flowers one might make a lot of garlands,

pdhp130:2.verse: so should many good deeds be done by one who is born a mortal.

pdhp131:1.verse: Who will conquer this earth and the lower realm, together with the gods?

pdhp131:2.verse: Who will win the well-taught verses of Dhamma as a good man wins a flower?

pdhp132:1.verse: The trainee will conquer this earth and the lower realm, together with the gods.

pdhp132:2.verse: He will win the well-taught verses of Dhamma as a good man wins a flower.

pdhp133:1.verse: Just as striped jasmine casts off its (…) flowers,

pdhp133:2.verse: so, monastics, cast off all passion and hatred.

pdhp134:1.verse: Knowing that this world is just like froth, it has the nature of a mirage to those who understand,

pdhp134:2.verse: cutting off Māra’s flower-tipped arrows, one should go beyond the King of Death’s sight.

pdhp135:1.verse: Just as in a forsaken rubbish heap along the highway

pdhp135:2.verse: a lotus might spring forth, with a pure fragrance, delighting the mind,

pdhp136:1.verse: so amongst the forsaken, the Perfect Sambuddha’s disciple

pdhp136:2.verse: outshines the blind and ordinary folk through his wisdom.

pdhp137:1.verse: For a human who lives life heedlessly craving increases like a clinging creeper,

pdhp137:2.verse: he rushes from one place to another like a monkey seeking fruit in the forest.

pdhp138:1.verse: That one who is overcome by these low cravings in the world, which are difficult to get past,

pdhp138:2.verse: for him griefs increase like grass that has been rained upon.

pdhp139:1.verse: Whoever overcomes this low craving in the world, which is difficult to get past,

pdhp139:2.verse: griefs roll from him like a drop of water on a lotus.

pdhp140:1.verse: This I say to you: “Good luck to as many as have assembled here”,

pdhp140:2.verse: dig up the root of craving, like one seeking the root digs up grass,

pdhp140:3.verse: for one who has cut off the root of craving there are no griefs, how is there fear?

pdhp141:1.verse: A man with craving as companion has a long time in births-and-deaths,

pdhp141:2.verse: in this existence or another existence, here and there, again and again.

pdhp142:1.verse: Having understood the danger, that craving is the origination of suffering,

pdhp142:2.verse: free from craving, without attachment, the monastic should wander mindfully.

pdhp143:1.verse: That bondage is not so strong say the wise, that is made of iron or wood or reeds,

pdhp143:2.verse: impassioned and excited they seek out jewels and earrings and children and wives—

pdhp144:1.verse: that bondage is strong say the wise, dragging down, subtle, hard to get free from,

pdhp144:2.verse: having cut this down the good go peacefully seeking nothing, abandoning all suffering.

pdhp145:1.verse: Not through a rain of coins is satisfaction found for sense desires,

pdhp145:2.verse: the wise one knowing: “Sense pleasures have little joy, much suffering,”

pdhp146:1.verse: does not find delight even in heavenly pleasures.

pdhp146:2.verse: The disciple of the Perfect Sambuddha delights in craving’s destruction.

pdhp147:1.verse: Without craving, without attachment, skilled in words and their explanation,

pdhp147:2.verse: knowing how syllables are arranged, which come before and which after,

pdhp147:3.verse: the one in his final body is said to be one of great wisdom.

pdhp148:1.verse: There are flowing streams of affection and mental happinesses for a person,

pdhp148:2.verse: pleasure-dependent they seek happiness, those people undergo birth and old age.

pdhp149:1.verse: People surrounded by craving crawl round like a hare in a trap,

pdhp149:2.verse: they are attached and clinging to fetters, they come back again and again to the womb for a long time.

pdhp150:1.verse: Be free of the past, be free of the future, be free of the present, after crossing over all existence,

pdhp150:2.verse: with mind liberated in every way, you will not return to birth and old age.

pdhp151:1.verse: The one who is free from desires, who is free in the forest, though free from the forest, runs back to the forest,

pdhp151:2.verse: come here and look at that person, though free, he runs back to bondage.

pdhp152:1.verse: Fields are ruined by grassy weeds, these people are ruined by passion,

pdhp152:2.verse: therefore there is great fruit for that given to those without passion.

pdhp153:1.verse: Fields are ruined by grassy weeds, these people are ruined by hatred,

pdhp153:2.verse: therefore there is great fruit for that given to those without hatred.

pdhp154:1.verse: Fields are ruined by grassy weeds, these people are ruined by delusion,

pdhp154:2.verse: therefore there is great fruit for that given to those without delusion.

pdhp155:1.verse: The delightful wilderness wherein the people do not delight,

pdhp155:2.verse: those without passion delight therein, but not those who seek sense pleasures.

pdhp156:1.verse: Just as when the root remains firm and undamaged though the tree was cut down, it springs up again,

pdhp156:2.verse: so when the tendency to craving is not rooted out this suffering appears again and again.

pdhp157:1.verse: Lack of repetition is the ruin of the Vedā, a lack of maintenance is the ruin of homes,

pdhp157:2.verse: indolence is the ruin of one’s appearance, heedlessness is the ruin of those on guard.

pdhp158:1.verse: Bad conduct is a woman’s stain, stinginess is a giver’s stain,

pdhp158:2.verse: wicked deeds are a stain both in this world and in the next.

pdhp159:1.verse: I say there is a stain worse than that, ignorance is a deadly stain,

pdhp159:2.verse: after abandoning those stains, live without stains, monastics!

pdhp160:1.verse: As a rust stain arises from iron, and arisen from that, it eats it away,

pdhp160:2.verse: so with one who is overindulgent—his deeds lead him to a bad destiny.

pdhp161:1.verse: You are now a withered leaf, Yama’s men stand waiting for you,

pdhp161:2.verse: you stand at decay’s door, with no provisions for the journey found.

pdhp162:1.verse: You should strive and endeavour by yourself, like a smith, you should remove the stain,

pdhp162:2.verse: removing the stain, blemishless, you seek the second noble realm.

pdhp163:1.verse: The sage gradually, little by little, moment by moment,

pdhp163:2.verse: should remove the stain from himself, like a smith removes the stain from silver.

pdhp164:1.verse: Life is light for one without shame, he lives a life with defilements,

pdhp164:2.verse: backbiting and recklessness, with the bold courage of a crow.

pdhp165:1.verse: Life is hard when endowed with shame, for the one constantly seeking purity,

pdhp165:2.verse: for one sincere, and not reckless, looking for purity of life.

pdhp166:1.verse: Easy to see are others’ fault, but one’s own is hard to see,

pdhp166:2.verse: for one sifts other peoples’ faults like they were chaff,

pdhp166:3.verse: but conceals one’s own faults, like a crafty player conceals his defeat.

pdhp167:1.verse: Easily done are things not good, and unbeneficial for oneself,

pdhp167:2.verse: but that which is beneficial and good is supremely hard to do.

pdhp168:1.verse: Easily done are things not good, and unbeneficial for oneself,

pdhp168:2.verse: but only those beneficial and good are done by the wise.

pdhp169:1.verse: They are ashamed of what is not shameful, not ashamed of what is shameful,

pdhp169:2.verse: seeing fear in what is not fearful, not seeing fear in what is fearful,

pdhp169:3.verse: undertaking wrong views, beings go to a bad destiny.

pdhp170:1.verse: Finding blame in what is blameless, not perceiving blame in what is blameable,

pdhp170:2.verse: undertaking wrong views, beings go to a bad destiny.

pdhp171:1.verse: Finding the essential in the unessential, and perceiving the unessential in the essential,

pdhp171:2.verse: they do not understand what is the essential, and resort to wrong intention.

pdhp172:1.verse: Knowing the essential in what is essential, and the unessential in what is unessential,

pdhp172:2.verse: they understand what is essential, and resort to right intention.

pdhp173:1.verse: Engaging oneself in what is not suitable, not engaging in what is suitable,

pdhp173:2.verse: abandoning the good, grasping the loved, they envy those who endeavour for good.

pdhp174:1.verse: Stupid fools live having themselves as their own foes,

pdhp174:2.verse: committing wicked deeds, which produce bitter fruit.

pdhp175:1.verse: How could he do that deed, which, having done, one has regret,

pdhp175:2.verse: for which he has tears on his face, as the result follows him round.

pdhp176:1.verse: But that deed is well done, which, having done, one has no regret,

pdhp176:2.verse: for which he is pleased and happy, as the result follows him round.

pdhp177:1.verse: As far as learning arises for a fool, it is only to his disadvantage,

pdhp177:2.verse: it destroys the fool’s good quality, and it will destroy his head.

pdhp178:1.verse: He wishes for the respect that is lacking, and status amongst the monastics,

pdhp178:2.verse: for control in the living quarters, and worship amongst good families:

pdhp179:1.verse: “Householders and renunciants should think this was done by me,

pdhp179:2.verse: let none be a match for me, in all to be done and not done”,

pdhp180:1.verse: so does the fool think, meanwhile his desires and conceit increase.

pdhp180:2.verse: For the means to gains is one thing, the path going to Nibbāna another,

pdhp181:1.verse: thus seeing this as it really is the disciple of the Buddha

pdhp181:2.verse: should not delight in honours, but practise in solitude.

pdhp182:1.verse: The fool thinks there is success, when he speaks words that are rough,

pdhp182:2.verse: but for the one who knows, endurance is the success of the good.

pdhp183:1.verse: Without power is the power of him whose power is the power of a fool,

pdhp183:2.verse: reproach is not found for the powerful one, protected by Dhamma.

pdhp184:1.verse: The fool who conceives he is a fool, is at least wise in that matter,

pdhp184:2.verse: the fool who is proud of his wisdom, he is said to be a fool indeed.

pdhp185:1.verse: Long is the night for one who sleeps not, long is a league for one tired,

pdhp185:2.verse: long is the round of births and deaths for fools who know not True Dhamma.

pdhp186:1.verse: That man who wraps up rotting fish with the best fragrant grass,

pdhp186:2.verse: makes the fragrant grass smell rotten, and so with those who associate with fools.

pdhp187:1.verse: That man who wraps up pinwheel in flame-tree leaves,

pdhp187:2.verse: makes even the leaf fragrant, and so with those who associate with the wise.

pdhp188:1.verse: If one who does no wickedness associates with those who do,

pdhp188:2.verse: he is suspected of wickedness, and his disrepute increases.

pdhp189:1.verse: An associate associating with others who are touched by contacts,

pdhp189:2.verse: like a smeared arrow in a bunch, smears that which is unsmeared,

pdhp189:3.verse: fearing being smeared the wise one will not have wicked friends.

pdhp190:1.verse: Therefore knowing the result for oneself of the fruit container,

pdhp190:2.verse: he should not follow the bad one, the wise one should associate with the good one.

pdhp191:1.verse: Even if a fool attends on a wise man for his whole life long,

pdhp191:2.verse: he does not learn Dhamma, like the spoon learns not the taste of curry.

pdhp192:1.verse: If a perceptive man attends on a wise man even for a second,

pdhp192:2.verse: he quickly learns Dhamma, like the tongue learns the taste of curry.

pdhp193:1.verse: One should not despise a little wickedness thinking: it will not come to me,

pdhp193:2.verse: through the falling of water drops the water-pot is quickly filled,

pdhp193:3.verse: the fool, gathering bit by bit, becomes full of wickedness.

pdhp194:1.verse: One should not despise little merit thinking: it will not come to me,

pdhp194:2.verse: through the falling of water drops the water-pot is quickly filled,

pdhp194:3.verse: the wise one, gathering bit by bit, becomes full of merit.

pdhp195:1.verse: Neither going naked, nor matted hair, nor mud, nor fasting or lying on stony ground,

pdhp195:2.verse: dusty clothes, or striving while squatting, can purify a mortal who has not removed uncertainty.

pdhp196:1.verse: Even if he were to adorn himself, but is trained, peaceful, settled, living by Dhamma,

pdhp196:2.verse: and has put aside the stick towards all living beings, he is a brahmin, an ascetic, a monastic.

pdhp197:1.verse: Do not speak anything harsh, spoken to they might answer back to you,

pdhp197:2.verse: for arrogant talk entails misery, and they might strike you back with a stick.

pdhp198:1.verse: If you make a sound like a gong that is struck,

pdhp198:2.verse: you will undergo the rounds of births and deaths for a long time.

pdhp199:1.verse: If you make no sound like a gong that is not struck,

pdhp199:2.verse: you are like one who has attained Nibbāna, contention is not found in you.

pdhp200:1.verse: Like a cowherd with a stick drives cattle to pasture,

pdhp200:2.verse: so do old age and death overpower living beings.

pdhp201:1.verse: Like a cowherd with a stick protects the owner’s cattle,

pdhp201:2.verse: so one should watch over oneself, and you should not let the moment pass,

pdhp201:3.verse: for when the chance has passed they grieve when consigned to the underworld.

pdhp202:1.verse: Everyone trembles at sticks, for all of them life is dear,

pdhp202:2.verse: comparing oneself with others, one should not hurt or have them hurt.

pdhp203:1.verse: One who harms with a stick beings who desire happiness,

pdhp203:2.verse: while seeking happiness for himself, won’t find happiness after death.

pdhp204:1.verse: One who harms not with a stick beings who desire happiness,

pdhp204:2.verse: while seeking happiness for himself, will find happiness after death.

pdhp205:1.verse: One should not keep company with wicked friends, one should not keep company with the ignoble,

pdhp205:2.verse: you should keep company with the sage and wise, you should keep company with superior people.

pdhp205:3.verse: keeping company with such is surely better for you, not worse.

pdhp206:1.verse: One should regard someone who shows your faults just like one who points out hidden treasure,

pdhp206:2.verse: one should keep company with such a sagacious person who reproves you;

pdhp206:3.verse: keeping company with such is surely better for you, not worse.

pdhp207:1.verse: One should advise and instruct, and forbid whatever is vile,

pdhp207:2.verse: for this is dear to the good, but it is not dear to the bad.

pdhp208:1.verse: Therefore the good and the bad from here go to various destinies,

pdhp208:2.verse: the bad go to the underworld, the good cross over to heaven.

pdhp209:1.verse: The person of little learning increases in age like an ox,

pdhp209:2.verse: for although his flesh does increase, his wisdom does not increase.

pdhp210:1.verse: There are four states the man who is heedless, the man who consorts with other man’s wives, undergoes:

pdhp210:2.verse: he gains demerit, an uncomfortable bed, blame as third, and rebirth in the underworld as fourth.

pdhp211:1.verse: Gaining demerit and a bad destiny, and only the little delight of a scared man with a scared woman,

pdhp211:2.verse: and kings who apply heavy punishment, at the break up of the body he goes to the underworld.

pdhp212:1.verse: The restrained go to a good destiny, the unrestrained go to a bad destiny,

pdhp212:2.verse: thinking: “I should not exhibit confidence,” the wise one wanders peacefully.

pdhp213:1.verse: Do not, elephant, approach the Buddha, for there is suffering, elephant, in approaching the Buddha,

pdhp213:2.verse: for the one who attacks the Buddha, elephant, does not go from here to a good destiny.

pdhp214:1.verse: As a lion wanders his mountain fortress, his resort on the mountainside,

pdhp214:2.verse: do not hurt the man-hero, the one without fear, the one of superior effort.

pdhp215:1.verse: Like an elephant in battle endures arrows shot from bow

pdhp215:2.verse: so will I endure abuse, for many people are unvirtuous.

pdhp216:1.verse: Many people shaken by fear go for refuge

pdhp216:2.verse: to mountains and woods, to places with beautiful trees.

pdhp217:1.verse: That is not a secure refuge, that is not the refuge supreme,

pdhp217:2.verse: nor is it the refuge to come to that liberates from all suffering.

pdhp218:1.verse: Whoever has gone for refuge to the Buddha, the Dhamma and the Saṅgha,

pdhp218:2.verse: and who sees as it really is the four noble truths.

pdhp219:1.verse: That is a secure refuge, that is the refuge supreme,

pdhp219:2.verse: that is the refuge to come to that liberates from all suffering.

pdhp220:1.verse: If, when cows are crossing a road, their leader goes crookedly,

pdhp220:2.verse: they all will go crookedly, as their guide crookedly does go.

pdhp221:1.verse: So it is with humans, he who is agreed upon as chief,

pdhp221:2.verse: if he lives unrighteously, so will other people.

pdhp222:1.verse: If, when cows are crossing a road, their leader goes straight,

pdhp222:2.verse: they all will go straight, as their guide straight does go;

pdhp223:1.verse: so it is with humans, he who is agreed upon as chief,

pdhp223:2.verse: if he lives righteously, so will other people.

pdhp224:1.verse: One should live by Dhamma, with good conduct, not with bad conduct,

pdhp224:2.verse: living by Dhamma one lives at ease in this world and the next.

pdhp225:1.verse: One should live by Dhamma, with good conduct, not with bad conduct,

pdhp225:2.verse: living the holy life one lives at ease in this world and the next.

pdhp226:1.verse: The one who finds pleasure in the Dhamma, delights in Dhamma, reflects on Dhamma,

pdhp226:2.verse: the monastic who remembers Dhamma, does not abandon the Dhamma.

pdhp227:1.verse: The Dhamma protects the one who lives by the Dhamma, the Dhamma well-practised is set on happiness,

pdhp227:2.verse: this is the advantage of the Dhamma well-practised, he who lives by the Dhamma does not go to a bad destination.

pdhp228:1.verse: The Dhamma protects the one who lives by the holy life, the Dhamma well-practised is set on happiness,

pdhp228:2.verse: this is the advantage of the Dhamma well-practised, he who lives the holy life does not go to a bad destination.

pdhp229:1.verse: Not having lived the holy life, not having gained wealth in their youth,

pdhp229:2.verse: they waste away like herons in a small lake devoid of fish.

pdhp230:1.verse: Not having lived the holy life, not having gained wealth in their youth,

pdhp230:2.verse: they lie like shafts scattered from a bow, wailing about things in the past.

pdhp231:1.verse: The mindful ones who are striving do not delight in a dwelling,

pdhp231:2.verse: like geese who abandon a lake, they abandon fondness for homes.

pdhp232:1.verse: As geese go through the path of the sky, they go through the sky by their power,

pdhp232:2.verse: the wise are led out in the world, after crushing Māra and his army.

pdhp233:1.verse: Why this laughter, why this joy, when the world is constantly burning,

pdhp233:2.verse: when thrown into darkness, do you not seek for a light?

pdhp234:1.verse: As a town in the border districts is guarded on the inside and the outside,

pdhp234:2.verse: so one should protect oneself, and you should not let the moment pass,

pdhp234:3.verse: for when the chance has passed they grieve when consigned to the underworld.

pdhp235:1.verse: Not through being shaven is one an ascetic, if one lacks vows, speaks lies,

pdhp235:2.verse: and is endowed with greed and desire, how will one be an ascetic?

pdhp236:1.verse: The one who quenches wicked deeds, small and great, in every way—

pdhp236:2.verse: through the appeasing of wicked deeds he is said to be an ascetic.

pdhp237:1.verse: For the one in whom thirty-six streams consisting of contact with conceit are strong,

pdhp237:2.verse: the one with wrong view is carried off by the flow of his greedy intentions.

pdhp238:1.verse: One should abandon anger, one should abandon conceit, one should overcome every fetter,

pdhp238:2.verse: without clinging to mind and bodily form, sufferings never do befall the one having no possessions.

pdhp239:1.verse: Enduring patience is the supreme austerity, Nibbāna is supreme say the Buddhas,

pdhp239:2.verse: for one gone forth does not hurt another, nor does an ascetic harass another.

pdhp240:1.verse: Those sages without violence, constantly restrained in body,

pdhp240:2.verse: go to the deathless Nibbāna, having gone there they do not grieve.

pdhp241:1.verse: Gotama’s disciples always awake to a good wakening,

pdhp241:2.verse: those who day and night have a mind that delights in non-violence.

pdhp242:1.verse: Gotama’s disciples always awake to a good wakening,

pdhp242:2.verse: those who day and night have a mind that delights in cultivation.

pdhp243:1.verse: Gotama’s disciples always awake to a good wakening,

pdhp243:2.verse: those who day and night constantly have mindfulness of the body.

pdhp244:1.verse: Those wise ones intent on meditation, who delight in the peace of renunciation,

pdhp244:2.verse: even the gods are envious of them, the Sambuddhas, the ones who are mindful.

pdhp245:1.verse: Whether in the wilds or village, whether on low or on high ground,

pdhp245:2.verse: wherever the Arahats live, that ground is surely delightful.

pdhp246:1.verse: If, for even one living being, one with an uncorrupt mind, has loving-kindness, there is wholesomeness in that,

pdhp246:2.verse: but the one with compassion in mind for all living beings, that noble one makes abundant merit.

pdhp247:1.verse: Those who conquered the earth, crowded with beings, those royal seers who went round sacrificing:

pdhp247:2.verse: the horse sacrifice, the man sacrifice, the stick-casting, the soma offering, the unobstructed—

pdhp247:3.verse: compared to the one who develops his mind with loving-kindness, they do not partake of even a sixteenth part,

pdhp247:4.verse: just as the whole host of stars do not partake of the radiance of the moon.

pdhp248:1.verse: Then he who with a mind of loving-kindness has compassion for all living beings,

pdhp248:2.verse: having loving-kindness towards all beings, he has no one who is hated.

pdhp249:1.verse: For he who every day and night delights in a mind of non-violence,

pdhp249:2.verse: having loving-kindness towards all beings, he has no one who is hated.

pdhp250:1.verse: For he who every day and night has a mind that delights in cultivation,

pdhp250:2.verse: having loving-kindness towards all beings, he has no one who is hated.

pdhp251:1.verse: For he who every day and night constantly has mindfulness of the body,

pdhp251:2.verse: having loving-kindness towards all beings, he has no one who is hated.

pdhp252:1.verse: He who neither kills, nor has killed, conquers, nor has conquered,

pdhp252:2.verse: having loving-kindness towards all beings, he has no one who is hated.

pdhp253:1.verse: For not by hatred do hatreds cease at any time in this place,

pdhp253:2.verse: they only cease with non-hatred, this truth is surely eternal.

pdhp254:1.verse: The others do not understand that we should be successful here,

pdhp254:2.verse: but for those here who do understand, through that, their dissensions do cease.

pdhp255:1.verse: Let us live truly happily, without hatred, amongst those who have hatred,

pdhp255:2.verse: amongst humans who have hatred let us live without hatred.

pdhp256:1.verse: Let us live truly happily, without longing, amongst those who are longing,

pdhp256:2.verse: amongst humans who are longing let us live without longing.

pdhp257:1.verse: We live truly happily enough having no possessions ourselves,

pdhp257:2.verse: amongst those with possessions let us live having no possessions.

pdhp258:1.verse: One should see it as a bubble, one should see it as a mirage,

pdhp258:2.verse: looking on the world in this way the King of Death does not see one.

pdhp259:1.verse: This body is worn out, a nest of disease, perishing,

pdhp259:2.verse: the putrid body comes to destruction, for life ends in death.

pdhp260:1.verse: Having seen an old man, one afflicted and sick, having seen one deceased, after not long for the student,

pdhp260:2.verse: anxiety, sharp and extensive, arose, and the wise one cut the household bonds.

pdhp261:1.verse: Amongst humans few people go beyond,

pdhp261:2.verse: the rest of the people run down the bank,

pdhp262:1.verse: but those who live righteously, conforming with this well-taught Dhamma,

pdhp262:2.verse: those folk will go beyond the realm of death, which is very hard to cross.

pdhp263:1.verse: Having abandoned the dark state, the wise ones should develop the bright,

pdhp263:2.verse: having gone forth to homelessness from home; in solitude, where it is hard to delight,

pdhp264:1.verse: one should seek to delight in that place, having given up sense pleasures, and having no possessions,

pdhp264:2.verse: he should purify the self of defilements of mind in every way.

pdhp265:1.verse: For he who has well developed with peaceful mind the factors of complete awakening,

pdhp265:2.verse: having given up the self, those who delight in being unattached,

pdhp265:3.verse: pollutant-free, shining forth, are emancipated in the world.

pdhp266:1.verse: That to be done is rejected, but what is not to be done is done,

pdhp266:2.verse: for the insolent, the heedless, their pollutants increase.

pdhp267:1.verse: But for those who always properly undertake mindfulness of the body

pdhp267:2.verse: who do not practice what is not to be done, persisting in what is to be done,

pdhp267:3.verse: for those mindful ones, those fully aware, their pollutants are destroyed.

pdhp268:1.verse: Those who look for others’ fault, who constantly perceive offence,

pdhp268:2.verse: for them the pollutants increase, they are far from their destruction.

pdhp269:1.verse: For those devoted to being alert, who train both by day and by night,

pdhp269:2.verse: who are intent on Nibbāna, the pollutants are laid to rest.

pdhp270:1.verse: For those whose pollutants are destroyed, who are not dependent on the foods,

pdhp270:2.verse: for those whose resort is the liberation that is empty or signless,

pdhp270:3.verse: like the birds in the sky, their footprint is hard to find.

pdhp271:1.verse: Not even through virtue or vows, or again through great learning,

pdhp271:2.verse: or through the attainment of concentration, or through a secluded dwelling,

pdhp272:1.verse: do we attain the happiness of renunciation, not practised by worldly people;

pdhp272:2.verse: let a monastic not be confident as long as the destruction of the pollutants is unattained.

pdhp273:1.verse: This is not the time to be heedless, while the destruction of the pollutants is unattained,

pdhp273:2.verse: heedless he follows suffering, like the mother of deer follows the lion.

pdhp274:1.verse: Some fall back into the womb, but those who are wicked in the underworld,

pdhp274:2.verse: the righteous go to heaven, those who are pollutant-free are emancipated.

pdhp275:1.verse: Like a lake that is deep, clear and unruffled,

pdhp275:2.verse: just so the wise are confident after listening to Dhamma.

pdhp276:1.verse: He whose victory cannot be undone, whose victory does not come to an end,

pdhp276:2.verse: the Buddha, the one of superior effort, by what path will you lead the pathless one?

pdhp277:1.verse: For him there is no desire, attachment, or craving to lead him anywhere,

pdhp277:2.verse: the Buddha, whose range is endless, by what path will you lead the pathless one?

pdhp278:1.verse: Verbally guarded, well-restrained in mind, he who does not practice a wrong deed with the body,

pdhp278:2.verse: purifying these three paths of action, would attain the unsurpassed state of peace.

pdhp279:1.verse: One should guard against bodily faults, one should be restrained bodily,

pdhp279:2.verse: abandoning wrong bodily conduct, one should have good bodily conduct.

pdhp280:1.verse: One should guard against verbal faults, one should be restrained verbally,

pdhp280:2.verse: abandoning wrong verbal conduct, one should have good verbal conduct.

pdhp281:1.verse: One should guard against mental faults, one should be restrained mentally,

pdhp281:2.verse: abandoning wrong mental conduct, one should have good mental conduct.

pdhp282:1.verse: The wise are restrained bodily, verbally and also mentally,

pdhp282:2.verse: the wise are restrained in every way, they are indeed very well-restrained.

pdhp283:1.verse: This is something of old, Ādhora, this is not something of today:

pdhp283:2.verse: they blame the one who sits silently, they blame the one who talks in moderation,

pdhp283:3.verse: they blame the one who talks a lot, there is no one in the world not blamed.

pdhp284:1.verse: There was not and there will not be, and at present there is not found

pdhp284:2.verse: a person totally blameworthy, or one totally praiseworthy.

pdhp285:1.verse: He who would worship or reproach the one who is unrighteous,

pdhp285:2.verse: a fool with lack of intelligence, that is to no purpose.

pdhp286:1.verse: The one who, after being examined day by day, is praised by the wise,

pdhp286:2.verse: faultless in conduct, sagacious, attending to virtue and wisdom,

pdhp287:1.verse: one who is like a golden coin, who is there worthy to blame him?

pdhp287:2.verse: That one is praised by the gods, and has been praised by the Brahmās too.

pdhp288:1.verse: Not by eloquence only, or by a beautiful complexion,

pdhp288:2.verse: is a person honourable, if still jealous, selfish and deceitful.

pdhp289:1.verse: In whom is truth, Dhamma, abstinence, restraint and good training,

pdhp289:2.verse: that sage who has thrown out hatred is said to be honourable.

pdhp290:1.verse: Even though reciting abundant scriptures, the heedless fellow, who does not do what they say,

pdhp290:2.verse: like a cowboy counting other’s cattle, does not partake of the ascetic life.

pdhp291:1.verse: Even though reciting but few scriptures, but living righteously in accordance with Dhamma,

pdhp291:2.verse: abandoning greed, hate and delusion, with mind released, completely without doubt,

pdhp291:3.verse: that one, unattached here and hereafter, surely partakes of the ascetic life.

pdhp292:1.verse: One should speak out the truth, one should not get angry, when requested you should give, if only a little,

pdhp292:2.verse: through these three conditions one can go to the presence of the gods.

pdhp293:1.verse: The miserly go not to the world of the gods, fools surely do not praise giving,

pdhp293:2.verse: but the wise one rejoices in giving, and through that he goes to the world of the gods.

pdhp294:1.verse: Having virtue, being pure and clever, principled, knowing the truths,

pdhp294:2.verse: the good one doing the deeds that are his own, that one the people love.

pdhp295:1.verse: It’s better to have eaten glowing iron balls, like flames of fire,

pdhp295:2.verse: than that the monastic who is unrestrained and unvirtuous should enjoy the country’s almsfood.

pdhp296:1.verse: As kusa grass, wrongly grasped, cuts into the hand,

pdhp296:2.verse: so does the ascetic life, wrongly grasped, drag one down to the underworld.

pdhp297:1.verse: For the person speaking falsely, who has transgressed in this one thing,

pdhp297:2.verse: who has abandoned the next world, there is no wickedness left undone.

pdhp298:1.verse: For not a well-sharpened sword, or even deadly poison,

pdhp298:2.verse: destroy quite as quickly as words that are badly spoken.

pdhp299:1.verse: For with the birth of a man an axe is born in his mouth,

pdhp299:2.verse: with which he cuts himself speaking a word that is badly spoken.

pdhp300:1.verse: He who praises the blameworthy, or he who blames the praiseworthy,

pdhp300:2.verse: piles up bad fortune with his mouth, and because of that bad fortune he does not find happiness.

pdhp301:1.verse: (Compared to) he who has a small measure of bad fortune through dice and loses his wealth,

pdhp301:2.verse: everything (he owns), together with his self;

pdhp301:3.verse: this is indeed a far greater bad fortune: he who has a corrupt mind aimed at those faring well.

pdhp302:1.verse: For one hundred and thirty-six thousand nirabbudas, and five abbudas,

pdhp302:2.verse: he goes to hell through reproaching the noble ones, having wicked verbal and mental intentions.

pdhp303:1.verse: He should speak wholesomely, he should not speak wickedly,

pdhp303:2.verse: the speaking of what is wholesome is best, having spoken wickedly he suffers.

pdhp304:1.verse: He should practice wholesomely, he should not speak wickedly,

pdhp304:2.verse: the speaking of what is wholesome is best, having spoken wickedly he suffers.

pdhp305:1.verse: He should speak wholesome words, he should not speak wickedly,

pdhp305:2.verse: arisen anger he should constrain, he ceases from hatred.

pdhp306:1.verse: The one who has an exceeding lack of virtue, like a deadly creeper covering a Sal tree,

pdhp306:2.verse: makes himself the same as his enemy wishes him to be.

pdhp307:1.verse: That wickedness done by oneself, born in oneself, arising in oneself,

pdhp307:2.verse: crushes the one who is stupid, as a diamond crushes a rock-jewel.

pdhp308:1.verse: By oneself alone is a wicked deed done, by oneself is one defiled,

pdhp308:2.verse: by oneself is a wicked deed left undone, by oneself is one purified,

pdhp308:3.verse: purity and impurity come from oneself, for no one purify another.

pdhp309:1.verse: Not the wrongs of others, or what others have done or have not done

pdhp309:2.verse: one should consider, but what has been done and not done by oneself.

pdhp310:1.verse: Not the wrongs of others, or what is just and unjust for others

pdhp310:2.verse: one should consider, but what is just and unjust for oneself.

pdhp311:1.verse: If one regards oneself as dear one should guard oneself right well,

pdhp311:2.verse: for happiness is not easy to gain by those who do wrong.

pdhp312:1.verse: If one regards oneself as dear one should guard oneself right well,

pdhp312:2.verse: during one of the three watches of the night the wise one should stay alert.

pdhp313:1.verse: Sitting alone, lying down alone, walking alone, diligent,

pdhp313:2.verse: the solitary one who delights in himself will delight in the edge of a forest.

pdhp314:1.verse: Whoever reviles the worthy teaching of the Noble Ones who live by Dhamma,

pdhp314:2.verse: that stupid one, depending on wicked views,

pdhp314:3.verse: makes himself the same as his enemy wishes him to be.

pdhp315:1.verse: Whoever reviles the worthy teaching of the Noble Ones who live by Dhamma,

pdhp315:2.verse: that stupid one, depending on wicked views,

pdhp315:3.verse: like the bamboo when it bears fruit, brings about his own destruction.

pdhp316:1.verse: First one should establish oneself in the good and the Dhamma,

pdhp316:2.verse: then one can advise another, saying: ‘You must be as I am’.

pdhp317:1.verse: First one should commit oneself to what is suitable,

pdhp317:2.verse: then when advising another, the wise one should not have any defilement.

pdhp318:1.verse: He should do himself as he would advise another to do,

pdhp318:2.verse: being untrained, he should surely train himself, for it is said the self is difficult to train.

pdhp319:1.verse: A tamed self is better than that of other people,

pdhp319:2.verse: for the person who conquers himself, who lives always well-restrained,

pdhp320:1.verse: neither gods, nor gandhabbas, nor Māra together with Brahmās,

pdhp320:2.verse: can turn conquest into defeat for a person who is like this.

pdhp321:1.verse: For the self is the friend of self, for what other friend would there be?

pdhp321:2.verse: When the self is well-practiced, one finds a friend that is hard to find.

pdhp322:1.verse: Self is the protector of self, self is the refuge of self,

pdhp322:2.verse: therefore one should restrain oneself, as a merchant restrains his noble horse.

pdhp323:1.verse: One should tame oneself always, that will be for a good destiny,

pdhp323:2.verse: be tamed, be peaceful, be upright, and from that be honest,

pdhp323:3.verse: then, tamed, be happy, unattached and cooled down.

pdhp324:1.verse: By oneself one should censure self, by oneself one should be controlled,

pdhp324:2.verse: he who guards himself, mindful, will live happily, monastic.

pdhp325:1.verse: One should not neglect one’s own good for another’s, however great;

pdhp325:2.verse: knowing further what is good for oneself should be the supreme good.

pdhp326:1.verse: Not for one’s own sake and not for another’s sake, not desiring heaven, riches, or a kingdom—

pdhp326:2.verse: he should not desire his success through corruption; he should be both virtuous and wise and righteous.

pdhp327:1.verse: The people give according to faith, according to their confidence,

pdhp327:2.verse: herein the one who becomes depressed because of food and drink given to others,

pdhp327:3.verse: does not, either by day or night, attain to good concentration.

pdhp328:1.verse: For the one in whom this depression is cut off, destroyed at the root, dug up,

pdhp328:2.verse: does, by day and night, attain to good concentration.

pdhp329:1.verse: Like a good horse touched by the whip, living ardent and spiritually intense.

pdhp329:2.verse: Having faith, virtue and energy, concentration and insight into the Dhamma,

pdhp329:3.verse: well-established in patience, meekness and concentration, they have come to the essence of wisdom and learning.

pdhp330:1.verse: He who acquires faith and wisdom unsurpassed in this very life,

pdhp330:2.verse: has great wealth in the world, other wealth, though great, is useless.

pdhp331:1.verse: The faithful one who is possessed of virtue, and has wealth and fame,

pdhp331:2.verse: whatever district he resorts to, right there and then he is worshipped.

pdhp332:1.verse: Faith is a person’s travelling companion, he would not accept travelling without faith,

pdhp332:2.verse: from that there will be fame and renown for him, and when he abandons the body he goes to heaven.

pdhp333:1.verse: The person who is beyond mere faith, who knows that which is unmade, who has cut off rebirth-linking,

pdhp333:2.verse: who has destroyed the occasion, who has thrown out hope and desire, is surely the person supreme.

pdhp334:1.verse: It is rare the arising of Buddhas, rare the teaching of the Dhamma,

pdhp334:2.verse: it is rare to acquire faith, rare is the life of mortals.

pdhp335:1.verse: For the one with unsettled mind, who does not know the True Dhamma,

pdhp335:2.verse: whose confidence is wavering, wisdom is unfulfilled.

pdhp336:1.verse: For one who has a mind lacking confidence, that is base or agitated,

pdhp336:2.verse: and frequently impetuous, it is not possible to understand the Dhamma.

pdhp337:1.verse: He who has removed impetuosity, displeasure from his mind,

pdhp337:2.verse: with confident mind, happy, he can understand well-spoken words.

pdhp338:1.verse: Acquiring birth as a human, or going to the heavens,

pdhp338:2.verse: or having sole sovereignty over the earth—better is the fruit of stream-entry.

pdhp339:1.verse: He whose faith in the Realised One is well-established and unmoveable,

pdhp339:2.verse: whose virtue is beautiful, praised by the noble ones,

pdhp340:1.verse: who has confidence in the Saṅgha, who sees uprightly,

pdhp340:2.verse: he they say is ‘not poor’, his life is not in vain.

pdhp341:1.verse: Therefore with faith, virtue, confidence and insight into Dhamma,

pdhp341:2.verse: a sage should devote himself to the essence of the Buddhas’ dispensation.

pdhp342:1.verse: An agitated, unsteady mind, difficult to guard, difficult to ward,

pdhp342:2.verse: the sagacious one makes straight, as a fletcher does his arrows.

pdhp343:1.verse: Like a fish thrown up on dry land, pulled out from its watery home,

pdhp343:2.verse: the mind is agitated, one ought to throw off the sway of Māra.

pdhp344:1.verse: Those who will restrain the mind that roams far,

pdhp344:2.verse: is lonesome, without a body, hidden, gain release from the bonds of Māra.

pdhp345:1.verse: For the mind that is difficult to subdue, flighty, flitting wherever it will,

pdhp345:2.verse: restraint is good, a restrained mind brings happiness.

pdhp346:1.verse: Hard to see, very subtle, flitting wherever it will,

pdhp346:2.verse: the sage should guard the mind, for guarded it brings happiness.

pdhp347:1.verse: For the one with mind that is not dependent, for the one with mind unperplexed,

pdhp347:2.verse: having abandoned the wholesome and demerit, for the watchful, there is no fear.

pdhp348:1.verse: The one who drinks the tasty Dhamma drink, with a clear mind,

pdhp348:2.verse: the wise one will always delight in the Dhamma that is made known by the Noble.

pdhp349:1.verse: Before long has passed by, alas, this body will lie on the ground,

pdhp349:2.verse: rejected, without consciousness, just like a useless piece of wood.

pdhp350:1.verse: Knowing this body is frail like a jar, govern the mind like a fortress,

pdhp350:2.verse: one should fight Māra with the weapon of wisdom, guard your success, and do not be attached.

pdhp351:1.verse: Just as the rain penetrates a house with thatching that is poor,

pdhp351:2.verse: so passion penetrates a mind that is undeveloped.

pdhp352:1.verse: Just as rain does not penetrate a house with thatching that is good,

pdhp352:2.verse: so passion cannot penetrate a mind that is well-developed.

pdhp353:1.verse: Just as the rain penetrates a house with thatching that is poor,

pdhp353:2.verse: so hatred penetrates a mind that is undeveloped.

pdhp354:1.verse: Just as rain does not penetrate a house with thatching that is good,

pdhp354:2.verse: so hatred cannot penetrate a mind that is well-developed.

pdhp355:1.verse: Just as the rain penetrates a house with thatching that is poor,

pdhp355:2.verse: so delusion penetrates a mind that is undeveloped.

pdhp356:1.verse: Just as rain does not penetrate a house with thatching that is good,

pdhp356:2.verse: so delusion cannot penetrate a mind that is well-developed.

pdhp357:1.verse: The non-doing of anything wicked, undertaking of what is good,

pdhp357:2.verse: the training of one’s mind—this is the teaching of the Buddhas.

pdhp358:1.verse: The eightfold is the best of paths, four principles the best of truths,

pdhp358:2.verse: dispassion the best of states, the Visionary the best of men.

pdhp359:1.verse: The path was declared by me, the removal of the dart by knowledge,

pdhp359:2.verse: your duty is to have ardour declare the Realised Ones,

pdhp359:3.verse: entering this path meditators will be released from the bonds of Māra.

pdhp360:1.verse: This is the path, there is no other, for insight and for purity,

pdhp360:2.verse: you should enter upon this path, this is the confounding of Māra,

pdhp360:3.verse: having entered upon this path you will make an end to suffering.

pdhp361:1.verse: Cut down the forest of defilements not just the trees, from the forest arises a danger,

pdhp361:2.verse: having cut down the forest and thicket, you will go further without forests.

pdhp362:1.verse: For as long as an atom of desire of a man for his kin is not cut down,

pdhp362:2.verse: the mind is in bondage there, like a calf in bondage to mother’s milk.

pdhp363:1.verse: Cut off any affection for one’s self, like an autumn lotus plucked with the hand,

pdhp363:2.verse: develop fully the path to peace and Nibbāna taught by the Fortunate One.

pdhp364:1.verse: Here I will make the rains retreat, here during winter and summer,

pdhp364:2.verse: in just such a way a fool thinks, not understanding the danger.

pdhp365:1.verse: That person whose mind is attached and besotted by cattle and children,

pdhp365:2.verse: is snatched away by death just as a sleeping village by a great flood.

pdhp366:1.verse: Children are not a refuge, nor fathers, not even brothers,

pdhp366:2.verse: for one afflicted by the End-Maker there is no refuge in relatives.

pdhp367:1.verse: Relatives cry and wail together in this way

pdhp367:2.verse: people still depart, against their desires they give him up.

pdhp368:1.verse: Understanding this the sage, wise, free of selfishness,

pdhp368:2.verse: should constantly purify the path that is leading to heaven.

pdhp369:1.verse: Therefore a wise man looking for his own welfare

pdhp369:2.verse: should constantly purify the path that is leading to heaven.

pdhp370:1.verse: Endowed with faith and virtue, wise, well-composed,

pdhp370:2.verse: one constantly purifies the path, which brings safety in the next world.

pdhp371:1.verse: Endowed with faith and virtue, wise, composed,

pdhp371:2.verse: delights in practising the path, delights in internal peace.

pdhp372:1.verse: Endowed with faith and virtue, always delighting in being wise,

pdhp372:2.verse: one advances like burning fire against the fetter, small or large,

pdhp372:3.verse: whether it is wicked conceit or hypocrisy.

pdhp373:1.verse: All conditions are impermanent, when one sees this with wisdom,

pdhp373:2.verse: then one grows tired of suffering—this is the path to purity.

pdhp374:1.verse: All components of mind and body are without self, when one sees this with wisdom,

pdhp374:2.verse: then one grows tired of suffering—this is the path to purity.

pdhp375:1.verse: From effort originates wisdom, without effort wisdom is destroyed,

pdhp375:2.verse: having understood these two paths of development and decline,

pdhp375:3.verse: the sage should train so that his wisdom increases.

pdhp376:1.verse: Though there are a thousand sayings consisting of useless words,

pdhp376:2.verse: better is one useful word, hearing which one is brought to peace.

pdhp377:1.verse: One may speak a thousand verses consisting of useless words,

pdhp377:2.verse: better is one verse of Dhamma, hearing which one is brought to peace.

pdhp378:1.verse: One may conquer a thousand men a thousand times in a battle,

pdhp378:2.verse: but having conquered another, one’s self, one would surely be supreme in battle.

pdhp379:1.verse: One might give alms impartially with a thousand coins of money month by month for a hundred years;

pdhp379:2.verse: and one might worship someone with developed self for a second—

pdhp379:3.verse: that worship is surely better than the hundred-year sacrifice.

pdhp380:1.verse: One person might care for the fire in the woods for a hundred years;

pdhp380:2.verse: and one might worship someone with developed self for a second—

pdhp380:3.verse: that worship is surely better than the hundred-year sacrifice.

pdhp381:1.verse: Whatever the alms or the sacrifice in the world the one seeking merit may give for a year,

pdhp381:2.verse: all that comes not to a quarter of the merit—better is the worship of the upright.

pdhp382:1.verse: One might give alms impartially with a thousand coins of money month by month for a hundred years;

pdhp382:2.verse: but that is not worth a sixteenth part of having confidence in the Buddha.

pdhp383:1.verse: One might give alms impartially with a thousand coins of money month by month for a hundred years;

pdhp383:2.verse: but that is not worth a sixteenth part of having confidence in the Dhamma.

pdhp384:1.verse: One might give alms impartially with a thousand coins of money month by month for a hundred years;

pdhp384:2.verse: but that is not worth a sixteenth part of having confidence in the Saṅgha.

pdhp385:1.verse: One might give alms impartially with a thousand coins of money month by month for a hundred years;

pdhp385:2.verse: but that is not worth a sixteenth part of those who have mastered Dhamma.

pdhp386:1.verse: From month to month the fool may eat food with the tip of kusa grass,

pdhp386:2.verse: but that is not worth a sixteenth part of having confidence in the Buddha.

pdhp387:1.verse: From month to month the fool may eat food with the tip of kusa grass,

pdhp387:2.verse: but that is not worth a sixteenth part of having confidence in the Dhamma.

pdhp388:1.verse: From month to month the fool may eat food with the tip of kusa grass,

pdhp388:2.verse: but that is not worth a sixteenth part of having confidence in the Saṅgha.

pdhp389:1.verse: From month to month the fool may eat food with the tip of kusa grass,

pdhp389:2.verse: but that is not worth a sixteenth part of those who have mastered Dhamma.

pdhp390:1.verse: One might live for a hundred years, unvirtuous and uncomposed,

pdhp390:2.verse: but a life of one day is better, for one with virtue and meditation.

pdhp391:1.verse: One might live for a hundred years, lacking in wisdom and uncomposed,

pdhp391:2.verse: but a life of one day is better, for one endowed with wisdom and meditation.

pdhp392:1.verse: One might live for a hundred years, indolent, with less energy,

pdhp392:2.verse: but a life of one day is better, for one with energy set up and firm.

pdhp393:1.verse: One might live for a hundred years, without seeing rise and fall,

pdhp393:2.verse: but a life of one day is better, for the one seeing rise and fall.

pdhp394:1.verse: One might live for a hundred years, without seeing the supreme state,

pdhp394:2.verse: but a life of one day is better, for one seeing the supreme state.

pdhp395:1.verse: One might live for a hundred years, without seeing the deathless state,

pdhp395:2.verse: but a life of one day is better, for one seeing the deathless state.

pdhp396:1.verse: One might live for a hundred years, unestablished in the True Dhamma,

pdhp396:2.verse: but a life of one day is better, for one who knows the True Dhamma.

pdhp397:1.verse: One might live for a hundred years, having not attained the destruction of the pollutants,

pdhp397:2.verse: but a life of one day is better, for one who has attained the destruction of the pollutants.

pdhp398:1.verse: That one who has not found any essence in existences, like one examining a fig tree does not find a flower,

pdhp398:2.verse: that monk abandons the near and far shore, like a snake who has abandoned its old, worn-out skin.

pdhp399:1.verse: That one who removes the passion that has arisen, as he would remove pervasive snake venom with medicines,

pdhp399:2.verse: that monk abandons the near and far shore, like a snake who has abandoned its old, worn-out skin.

pdhp400:1.verse: That one who removes the hatred that has arisen, as he would remove pervasive snake venom with medicines,

pdhp400:2.verse: that monk abandons the near and far shore, like a snake who has abandoned its old, worn-out skin.

pdhp401:1.verse: That one who removes the delusion that has arisen, as he would remove pervasive snake venom with medicines,

pdhp401:2.verse: that monk abandons the near and far shore, like a snake who has abandoned its old, worn-out skin.

pdhp402:1.verse: That one who removes the anger that has arisen, as he would remove pervasive snake venom with medicines,

pdhp402:2.verse: that monk abandons the near and far shore, like a snake who has abandoned its old, worn-out skin.

pdhp403:1.verse: That one who removes the conceit that has arisen, as he would remove pervasive snake venom with medicines,

pdhp403:2.verse: that monk abandons the near and far shore, like a snake who has abandoned its old, worn-out skin.

pdhp404:1.verse: That one who cuts off passion without remainder, like one who has plucked a lotus growing in a lake,

pdhp404:2.verse: that monk abandons the near and far shore, like a snake who has abandoned its old, worn-out skin.

pdhp405:1.verse: That one who cuts off hatred without remainder, like one who has plucked a lotus growing in a lake,

pdhp405:2.verse: that monk abandons the near and far shore, like a snake who has abandoned its old, worn-out skin.

pdhp406:1.verse: That one who cuts off delusion without remainder, like one who has plucked a lotus growing in a lake,

pdhp406:2.verse: that monk abandons the near and far shore, like a snake who has abandoned its old, worn-out skin.

pdhp407:1.verse: That one who cuts off anger without remainder, like one who has plucked a lotus growing in a lake,

pdhp407:2.verse: that monk abandons the near and far shore, like a snake who has abandoned its old, worn-out skin.

pdhp408:1.verse: That one who cuts off conceit without remainder, like one who has plucked a lotus growing in a lake,

pdhp408:2.verse: that monk abandons the near and far shore, like a snake who has abandoned its old, worn-out skin.

pdhp409:1.verse: That one who cuts off passion without remainder, having cut the bonds and attachments, like kusa grass,

pdhp409:2.verse: that monk abandons the near and far shore, like a snake who has abandoned its old, worn-out skin.

pdhp410:1.verse: That one who cuts off craving without remainder, having dried up that quick-flowing stream,

pdhp410:2.verse: that monk abandons the near and far shore, like a snake who has abandoned its old, worn-out skin.

pdhp411:1.verse: He who does not overstep the limit nor lag behind, who is completely free from the limits of this impediment,

pdhp411:2.verse: that monk abandons the near and far shore, like a snake who has abandoned its old, worn-out skin.

pdhp412:1.verse: He who does not overstep the limit nor lag behind, thinking: “all this is untrue,” a falsity,

pdhp412:2.verse: that monk abandons the near and far shore, like a snake who has abandoned its old, worn-out skin.

pdhp413:1.verse: For the one with no desire that has arisen, having a cause for bondage to existence,

pdhp413:2.verse: that monk abandons the near and far shore, like a snake who has abandoned its old, worn-out skin.

pdhp414:1.verse: For the one with no distress that has arisen, having uprooted all unwholesome roots,

pdhp414:2.verse: that monk abandons the near and far shore, like a snake who has abandoned its old, worn-out skin.

pdhp414:4.verse: Complete are the five hundred and two verses of the Dharma Verses, the Deathless Verses.

pdhp414:5.verse: As I saw, so I wrote, giving it our complete attention.

pdhp414:6.verse: May there be good for all beings!
